definitions.definition: to send out air from the mouth

examples.text: You're not blowing hard enough!
The policeman asked me to blow into the breathalyser.
He drew on his cigarette and blew out a stream of smoke.

phrases: see which way the wind is blowing

definitions.definition: when the wind or a current of air blows, it is moving; when it blows, the wind is blowing

examples.text: The birds were singing and a warm wind was blowing.
A cold wind blew from the east.
It was blowing hard.
It was **blowing a gale** *(= there was a strong wind)*.

phrases: see which way the wind is blowing

definitions.definition: to be moved by the wind, somebody’s breath, etc.; to move something in this way
definitions.sensetop: + adv./prep.+ adj.blow somebody/something + adv./prep.blow something + adj.

examples.text: My hat blew off.
The door blew open.
I was almost blown over by the wind.
She blew the dust off the book.
The ship was blown onto the rocks.
The bomb blast blew two passers-by across the street.
The wind blew the door shut.

phrases: see which way the wind is blowing

definitions.definition: if you blow a whistle, musical instrument, etc. or if a whistle, etc. blows, you produce a sound by blowing into the whistle, etc.

examples.text: the sound of trumpets blowing
The referee blew his whistle.

definitions.definition: to clear your nose by blowing strongly through it into a tissue or handkerchief

examples.text: She grabbed a tissue and loudly blew her nose.

definitions.definition: to kiss your hand and then pretend to blow the kiss towards somebody
to make or shape something by blowing

examples.text: to blow smoke rings
to **blow bubbles** *(= for example, by blowing onto a thin layer of water mixed with soap)*
to **blow glass** *(= to send a current of air into melted glass to shape it)*

definitions.definition: if a fuse blows or you blow a fuse, the electricity stops flowing suddenly because the fuse (= a thin wire) has melted because the current was too strong
to break open or apart, especially because of pressure from inside; to make a tyre break in this way

examples.text: The car spun out of control when a tyre blew.
The truck blew a tyre and lurched off the road.

definitions.definition: to break something open with explosives

examples.text: The safe had been blown by the thieves.

definitions.definition: to make known something that was secret

examples.text: One mistake could **blow your cover** *(= make your real name, job, intentions, etc. known)*.
We’re going to blow his operation wide open.

definitions.definition: to spend or waste a lot of money on something

examples.text: He inherited over a million dollars and blew it all on drink and gambling.

definitions.definition: to waste an opportunity

examples.text: She **blew her chances** by arriving late for the interview.
You had your chance and you **blew it**.

definitions.definition: used to show that you are annoyed, surprised or do not care about something

examples.text: Blow it! We've missed the bus.
Well, blow me down! I never thought I'd see you again.
**I'm blowed if** I'm going to *(= I certainly will not)* let him treat you like that.
Let's take a taxi and blow *(= never mind)* the expense.

definitions.definition: to leave a place suddenly

examples.text: Let's blow this joint.

definitions.definition: to kill yourself/somebody by shooting yourself/them in the head

examples.text: He put a gun to his head and threatened to blow his brains out.
While cleaning his shotgun he had accidentally blown his own brains out.

definitions.definition: to vomit
to help somebody have a fresh, lively state of mind again

examples.text: A brisk walk should blow the cobwebs away.

definitions.definition: to get very angry
to tell something secret, especially by mistake
to change your opinion about something often
to produce a very strong feeling of pleasure or shock

examples.text: Wait till you hear this. It'll blow your mind.
a collection of photographs that will blow your mind

definitions.definition: to get rid of your energy, anger or strong emotions by doing something active or noisy

examples.text: I went for a long walk to let off steam.
I like blowing off steam and I like saying things that shock people.

definitions.definition: to destroy somebody/something completely
to show that somebody/something is not good by being very much better than it/them

examples.text: I like my old phone, but this new model blows it out of the water.

definitions.definition: to praise your own abilities and achievements
to try to trick somebody or lie to somebody, particularly by saying something is better than it really is
to surprise or impress somebody very much
used by somebody who does not want to do something because it involves too much effort

examples.text: Sod that for a lark! I'm not doing any more tonight.

definitions.definition: to use bombs or other weapons to destroy somebody/something completely

examples.text: The plane was blown to pieces when the bomb exploded.

definitions.definition: to completely destroy somebody/something with an explosion

examples.text: The truck was blown to kingdom come.

definitions.definition: to get very angry
if a plan, etc. blows up in your face, it goes badly wrong in a way that causes you damage or makes you feel embarrassed
to tell somebody in authority about something wrong or illegal that somebody is doing
no problem is so bad that it does not bring some advantage to somebody
to tell people unpleasant facts about something

examples.text: Her article lifts the lid on bullying in the workplace.

definitions.definition: to breathe quickly and loudly through your mouth after physical effort

examples.text: Eventually, puffing and blowing, he arrived at the gate.

definitions.definition: to get an idea of what is likely to happen before deciding what to do

wordOrigin: verb Old English blāwan, of Germanic origin; related to German blähen ‘blow up, swell’, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin flare ‘blow’.
